examples.heading: 200 years that changed the world
examples.content:
200 years ago, all countries were poor and life expectancy was less than 40 years.

In the 1800s, health only improved in a few countries, but today no country have less than 40 years in life expectancy.

Watch this video clip with Hans Rosling for a more in-depth explanation.

examples.heading: Africa is not a country
examples.content:
There are huge differences between the countries in Africa. It's misleading to treat them as one and the same.

Life expectancy in Cape Verde is for example 22 years longer than in Swaziland, both are african countries.

Botswana is one of the top 13 achievers in the world when it comes to sustained economic growth. It has been democratic and peaceful since its independence. It is also an african country.

Democratic Republic of Congo is one of the most tragic economic disasters in the world. It has been plagued by despots and war since its independence. Millions have died since the Second Congo War broke out in 1998. It is the poorest country in the world. Congo DR is also an african country.

examples.heading: Asia best in math
examples.content:
The top five countries in an international math test are all East Asian countries.


The graph shows the average achievement for children in 8th grade. A higher score means better achievements in the test.
Click PLAY to see that scores haven't changed much over the last decade.

The data is based on an international math test for children in 4th and 8th grade, from the TIMSS (Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study).

examples.heading: Asia's rise - how and when?
examples.content:
When will India and China catch up with the US income per person?

Watch this YouTube video to see Hans Rosling's predictions based on this graph.

examples.heading: CO2 emissions since 1820
examples.content:
In 1820, at the dawn of the Industrial Revolution, United Kingdom emitted most CO2 - both per person and in total emissions.

Click Play to see how USA becomes the largest emitter of CO2 from 1900 onwards.
The vertical axis shows CO2-emissions per person and the size of the bubble shows total emissions for the country.


At the beginning of the 20th century, US and UK emissions where about the same.

examples.heading: Does geography matter?
examples.content:
There are very few landlocked countries, situated close to the equator, with high income.


The role of geography in development has been hotly debated over the last decade. Economists like Jeffrey Sachs have suggested that landlocked countries in the tropics, face tougher challenges.
In the graph you see Latitude - how far from the equator a country is - on the Y-axis. The color shows if a country is landlocked or not.
Low income is more common among countries situated close to the equator. At present, there are no high-income, landlocked countries close to the equator.

examples.heading: HIV epidemic 1980-2007
examples.content:
The graph displays percentage of people living with HIV and income per person.

The size of the bubbles shows the actual number of people living with HIV.

Click Play to see how countries have been affected from 1980 to 2007.
Hint: Select one or more countries to see how HIV-prevalence have increased or decreased over time.

examples.heading: HIV world map
examples.content:
Click PLAY to see the change in number of people living with HIV since 1980 (bubble size).

The color gradient shows the percentage of adults infected by HIV.

In a dozen countries, in southern and eastern Africa, more than 6% of the population is living with HIV. The percentage is much lower in most of Africa.

examples.heading: Is child mortality falling?
examples.content:
Is it possible to reach Millennium Development Goal 4: a reduction of child mortality with two thirds between 1990 and 2015.

Click PLAY to see for yourself.
Egypt and Turkey did it in only 15 years and Peru has also already met the goal.

In fact, 16 countries managed to reduce child mortality with 2/3 between 1990 and 2008 and another 43 is well on their way to do it by 2015.

The sad story is that 10 countries have the same or higher child mortality today than in 1990.

examples.heading: People killed in earthquakes
examples.content:
The size of the bubbles shows the number of people killed in earthquakes during a given year.

Click PLAY to see where earthquakes have occurred since 1970.

The data is from the Emergency Events Database.

examples.heading: People killed in floods
examples.content:
The size of the bubbles shows the number of people killed in floods during the given year.

Click PLAY to see where floods has occurred since 1970.

The data is from the Emergency Events Database.

examples.heading: Smaller families and longer lives
examples.content:
In the 1950s, most countries in Latin America, Asia and Africa had low life expectancy and high birth rates; in most cases, more than 5 children per women.

Only five decades later, most of those countries have less than three children per woman, and much longer lives.

See this TEDTalk for a more in-depth analysis by Hans Rosling.
Demographic transition is the transformation of countries from high birth rates and high death rates to low birth rates and low death rates as part of the economic development of a country.

examples.heading: The Bangladesh Miracle
examples.content:
Are you aware of the miracle that has taken place in Bangladesh?

40 years ago, 1 of 4 children died before the age of five. Today the situation is much better.

In 1970, one year before its independence from Pakistan, an average woman in Bangladesh gave birth to 7 children. One of four of these children died before the age of five. (The under-five mortality rate was almost 250 / 1000 born.)

But after independence things have improved. Click the play button to see the dramatic development. Today child mortality is 6% (instead of 24%) and the number of children per woman has gone down to 2.3.

Watch this video with Hans Rosling about the Bangladesh Miracle.

examples.heading: The rise, fall and rise of health in Botswana
examples.content:
In 1965, at independence, Botswana was a poor country with low life expectancy.

25 years of remarkable progress increased life expectancy with 15 years. This gain of life expectancy was lost during the 1990s due to the HIV-epidemic.
By 1988, Botswana had passed Turkey and caught up with Brazil.


Then HIV grew to tragic levels, causing life expectancy to fall by 17 years.

Over the past five years, treatment of infected persons has reduced AIDS-related deaths by over 50%. This has caused life expectancy to increase again.

Move the slider back and forth to see the country's development.

examples.heading: USA or China, who emits most CO2
examples.content:
An average American cause 4 times more CO2-emissions than a person in China.

However, due to its large population, China emits a lot of CO2 in total.

Does income matter?
Few countries in history have managed to combine high income with low CO2-emissions per person.

See for yourself by clicking the Play button.

examples.heading: Wealth & Health of Nations
examples.content:
This graph shows how long people live and how much money they earn.
Click the play button to see how countries have developed since 1800.

Explore more of Gapminder World:

  • browse example graphs
  • learn to select indicators and country bubbles

examples.heading: Who has the best teeth?
examples.content:
Are dental problems worst in the richest or the poorest countries?

In fact, middle-income countries seem to have the biggest dental problems, while the situation in both the richest and the poorest countries is generally better.

On the vertical axis, you see "Bad teeth per child", which shows how many decayed, missing or filled teeth an average 12-year-old has in each country.

The data comes from the WHO. Unfortunately, we only have data for one year.

Photo: guyfawkes

examples.heading: Who has the most Internet users?
examples.content:
Do you know which country has the highest percentage Internet users?

Chances are that Greenland is not you first guess. But that is the correct answer. There, 91 out of 100 people uses the Internet regularly.

High percentages, you also find in the Nordic countries, the US, Canada, Japan, South Korea and Singapore.

In New Zeeland, 7 of 10 are using the Internet regularly, which is more than countries like Japan, Spain or France. 

In China, 16% use Internet, in India less than 7% and in many countries the percentage of users is below 1%.

The income of Russia is more than 5 times the one of Vietnam, but the rate of Internet users is the same.

examples.heading: Yes, most billionaires live in the US
examples.content:
Not surprisingly, richer countries have more billionaires than poorer countries.

The size of the bubbles represents the total number of billionaires and the y-axis shows billionaires per million people.

USA, the big yellow bubble, had the largest number of billionaires, 415 persons, in 2007. This corresponded to 1.4 billionaires per 1 million people.

The list of US Dollar billionaires is updated by Forbes Magazine every year.
